trial_identification.studytitle: Prophylactic Coagulation for the Prevention of Bleeding in Endoscopic Mucosal Resection of Large Sessile Colonic Polyps
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Prophylactic Endoscopic Coagulation for the Prevention of Bleeding in Endoscopic Mucosal Resection (EMR) of Large Sessile Colonic Polyps: A Multi-centre, Randomised Control Trial

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other diseases of the mouth, teeth, oesophagus, digestive system including liver and colon

interventions.interventions:
Treatment: surgery - Prophylactic use of coagulation therapy
No Intervention: nil prophylactic coagulation -
Active Comparator: Prophylactic coagulation -
Treatment: surgery: Prophylactic use of coagulation therapy The procedure is completed as per usual, and if the patient has been randomized to the intervention group the appropriate coagulation therapy will be applied immediately after standard EMR to visible vessels within the mucosal resection area.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
- Patients referred to Westmead Hospital Endoscopy unit for endoscopic removal of a large sessile colonic polyp sized >20mm
- Age >18 years
- Able to give informed consent to involvement in trial
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
- Pregnancy: currently pregnant or attempting to become pregnant
- Lactation: currently breastfeeding
- Taken clopidogrel within 7 days
- Taken warfarin within 5 days
- Had full therapeutic dose unfractionated heparin within 6 hours
- Had full therapeutic dose low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) within 12 hours
- Known clotting disorder

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The hypothesis of this study is that prophylactic coagulation therapy with coagulation forceps to visible vessels within the mucosal defect for colonic Endoscopic Mucosal Resection (EMR) will reduce the rate of delayed bleeding when compared with current established standard EMR technique.
